title: Tuesday, 18th September 2018
bodyHTML:
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Yeah, yeah. Late. I know.

Blank canvas good morning everyone
GBKrona Hola!
Manxish Morning each
Soundbuy Morgen
wayneJ Morning
Airborne Cigar Slainte...
BE11:10am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's groundbreaking (a decade ago) liveblogging service.

BE11:10am

https://twitter.com/s_m_i/status/1041908711516598272

Pharma 11.11 is the new 11.
hedgehog spire ?
Shisho good morning
Markkus G'day
11:13 am
BE11:13am

That's us. Well, it was, back in the day. And SMI was one of the original (and one of the very best) Alphavillans, who's gone on to fight for considerably more important causes than typing about numbers and mucking about each day.

VV75 morning
BE11:14am

We, however, are still doing the latter. So I guess we should get on with it.

undefined
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Here was my favourite story of yesterday.

Airborne Cigar Back in the day the FT had multiple journos doing ML and didn't just leave BE hanging in the breeze...
BE11:14am

(Bloomberg) -- Spire Healthcare holders are said to be receptive to a new takeover approach from Mediclinic even if a bid were at a lower price than the previous offer, DealReporter writes, citing three unidentified minority shareholders of Spire.

BE11:14am

Teeth smile

Nately PM & NH, great double act
11:14 am
BE11:14am

One minority holder is quoted as saying a price “just north of GBP2.50 would probably be acceptable”

Nately All pre-scripted of course ;)
BE11:15am

Just the ~50% premium, then. That's "probably" acceptable.

Soundbuy ITV suffering again, off 4%. McCall really can't believe this is the best way forward.......£3bn......... shareholders no likey............
BE11:15am

Another minority holder sees value at ~GBP3/share for Spire, report says

11:15 am
BE11:16am

"I guess I'd consider accepting a ~75% takeover premium. Thanks for asking."

cheeckychappy @BE - I wonder how much a DealReporter "minority holder" owns of Spire?
BE11:16am

The shares went up on that yesterday afternoon!

BE11:16am

Today, however, sense returns.

11:16 am
Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 162.50, down 6.7 (-3.96%), High: 162.90, Low: 148.60, Volume: 4.18m
Waterloo So $200bn tariff at 10% with China saying it will immediately hit back. The market seems to 'like' that it was only 10% , but as soon as they retaliate he will either move those up to 25% or add a further $250bn (ie everything which is probably simpler). So he has two or three more rounds of retaliation. Not sure the market will like that though!
BE11:17am

Half years tell the usual story. NHS referrals drying up .....

pancakes or waffles China also rallying I think as there was a local article about govt contemplating "stabilising" investment i.e. stimulus
BE11:19am

As waiting lists are quietly managed to try and push anyone who can afford their elective procedure into the private sector.

pancakes or waffles The pain will be a lot more for the remaining untariffed goods for the US - consumer goods, high % of China share (so hard to switch), lack of substitutes
11:19 am
BE11:20am

Sadly, too few patients can afford it. So Spire's private business doesn't go up by the amount that its NHS business goes down.

BE11:20am

Which is pretty damning, really, when you think about it.

BE11:20am

So anyway, there was a trading update early August meaning it's all about the outlook.

11:20 am
BE11:21am

And FY guidance for adjusted EBITDA of £125-130m is lower than consensus of £132m

BE11:21am

Will cut to Morgan Stanley to summarise from there.

BE11:21am

As Spire adjusts to the new market environment, impairment losses have started to come through and, while Spire highlights a 5 year target of EBITDA of £200m, we see the path as unclear without a significant turnaround in trends, not just in the NHS business but also in Self-Pay and PMI where growth would need to accelerate.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Cost savings initiatives should bridge some of the gap with high single digit millions expected in FY19 and optimisation of hospitals and staff costs may help. However, without the NHS business stabilising, margin expansion towards the high teens level will be challenging, in our view. Over the next 5 years there could be opportunities to grow EBITDA either through competitor closures or through in-organic purchases of hospitals. With other private providers witnessing similar challenges, if Spire were able to triangulate those assets that could be consolidated within its own facilities, it could potentially gain market share and deliver significant synergies. This type of roll-up strategy could potentially create value for Spire and help it to increase utilisation in the Hospitals, which have struggled in recent years. However, with the group Net Debt / EBITDA for FY18E around 3.8x, there may be limited assets of the right size and value and the ability to do so may be limited. Therefore, to reach its margin markets, closure of competitor hospitals may be the more likely scenario, in our view.

cheeckychappy @BE - are you being a bit too mean to DealReporter...?
BE11:23am

Or Peel Hunt, to put it more succinctly.

Pharma @pancakes or waffles, wonder to what extent companies will have been looking for alternative suppliers. China no longer has the lowest labour costs, so there may be a tipping point where business is permanently lost.
FTsuisse Hi
BE11:23am

We always expected NHS revenues to decline (-2.8% for FY2018E), but were sufficiently concerned over the magnitude of declared H1 NHS deterioration between market updates (-9.5% for H1 2018) so moved to ‘under review’. Current share price at an all-time low below 2014 IPO of 215p vs our numbers however, implies a c40-50% cut to our in-year unadjusted NHS revenues (c£280m FY18 PHe from £288m FY17A). We think this reaction is included within the share price though we appreciate the outlook guidance on EBITDA may be met negatively.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

We think NHS revenue is all important – it underpins and enables the private business to grow (being a direct link to theatre lists and consultants). Therefore even though this makes up c25-30% of SPI revenues we need to get clarity on this before reconsidering the business.

BE11:24am

They don't have a recommendation right now.

undefined
11:24 am
BE11:24am

(@cheeckychappy: yes, I am.)

cheeckychappy @BE - LOL
pancakes or waffles @Pharma I would think so too but I thought companies where labour costs are the largest marginal cost have largely moved away from China already to other SE Asia countries
BE11:25am

Should get the day's bid out of the way.

Jardine Lloyd Thompson Group PLC (JLT:LSE): Last: 1,876, up 444 (+31.01%), High: 1,896, Low: 1,876, Volume: 1.04m
hedgehog any update on Aston Martin IPO ?
11:25 am
BE11:26am

Out of leftfield, this one, even though there had been plenty of noise about other insurers.

pancakes or waffles On the other hand, will companies eventually be forced to move back the US if tariffs become so punitive? I don't know the maths but I think the threshold is too high for that too happen
BE11:26am

Argument was always that JLT was relatively unlikely to be a takeover target because of Jardine Matheson's 40pc stake.

BE11:27am

Turns out they're sellers at the right price, which is about 30 times forward earnings as well as a pretty amazing 35pc more than yesterday.

pancakes or waffles Perhaps companies are thinking this admin is in at max for 2024, i.e. 6 years out, which is too short a time frame to drastically change up one's supply chain
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Jardine's gone hard irrevocable so, in combo with the knockout price, a counterbid seems pretty unlikely here.

Pharma Agree displacement to other SE Asia countries, or maybe eventually Africa, is more likely than a shift back to the US. Given that China is busy buying Africa wholesale, not sure the end result will be much different.
BE11:29am

Aon would be the only plausible counterbidder, really, but probably not at this price.

BE11:30am

So .... Marsh & McLennan has it. So says the sellside anyway. Here's RBC.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

At 26.6x our 2019E earnings, we see the price as attractive for JLT
shareholders. The company has developed a highly specialised business
delivering strong organic growth at decent trading margins. Based on
Bloomberg estimates, MMC trades on 18.35x 2019E earnings per share.
With a relatively high multiple for JLT, we see the potential for any
interloper being low, and with the support of both JMH and management
we expect that this deal will go through with few difficulties. In the past
we had seen the shareholding of JMH as being a reason that JLT might not get taken out, in fact JMH's support of JLT's independence from the big 3 brokers has helped JLT to win clients and attract staff.

BE11:30am

In the statement, MMC flagged that the acquisition of JLT would
strengthen its specialty broking business, expand the reinsurance
footprint of the company and enhance key growth markets such as Asia
and Latin America. We see this acquisition as validating JLT's focus on
expanding its specialty business in recent years. MMC has identified
around $250m of synergies within 3 years of the acquisition due to
some duplication between the two businesses with the savings expected
in headcount reductions (2-5% of the combined workforce mainly in
functional support areas), real estate, IT and other initiatives.

pancakes or waffles @Pharma, in the meantime I would think the Chinese are happy to wait out the near-term post-mid terms to see what happens
BE11:30am

With more consolidation in the broker space, the balance of power
continues to be in favour of the brokers vs underwriters in our view.
Putting the two companies together would add around 18% to MMC's
broking business (based on 2017 data) with total combined revenues in
the broking businesses of just under $9bn.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

And a line from the chaps at Olivetree.

BE11:32am

With a hard irrevocable in place and a commitment from MMC to do anything necessary to achieve regulatory approval (and note the absence of the word “reasonable” there), it is hard to see this acquisition being anything other than super clean. It is marginally curious that the companies guide for this to take c6 months to complete, without the usual onerous insurance regulatory approvals, this seems conservative in nature. The best comparable transaction would seem to be Willis and Towers Watson, which did need a lengthy list of approvals. It will be interesting to confirm that is isn’t the case for JLT, and if not why the timeline looks conservative. This would appear to be the biggest talking point however.

BE11:32am

The market is very fragmented, and with such a well-funded large acquirer, transaction risk is likely to be minimal in nature. This is despite the ongoing FCA market study of the wholesale insurance broker market. JLT shares will no doubt continue to trade tightly to the terms of the offer although shareholders should keep an eye out for the preliminary findings from the FCA, due soon.

11:32 am
undefined
Pharma The mid-terms will not change anything. Trump can't get anything through congress as it stands anyway, which is why he is busy with his trade war in the first place; no legislation required.
BE11:34am

Apologies, I've not been following the Aston Martin IPO terribly closely.

pancakes or waffles Yeah, but I'm thinking maybe the rhetoric dies down a tad if Dems manage to get a bit more of a wranglehold?
pancakes or waffles Either way, the remaining untariffed goods seems to be the "make-or-break" point here given the pain it will inflict if eventually tariffed
Excel Developer Trump got tax cut through congress.
Soundbuy Aston IPO - would worry over potential future litigation over those ejector seats..........
BE11:36am

Though the bad news for the process is what looks a lot like a Ferrari profit warning crossing the tape.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

FERRARI REVISES 2022 ADJ EBITDA TARGET TO EU1.8B-EU2B

hornblower small cap but any comment on Flowtech -28% on marginal downgrade
pancakes or waffles @Excel I'm not familiar w/ US politics enough but didn't those cuts go through because there was a lower approval ratio needed given their temporary nature
BE11:38am

Trying to find the actual statement ......... and word to the wise, don't search "Ferrari" on Twitter while you're at work ..... yikes ......

alewis2005 ferarri is now a NSFW term?
Electric Dragon @Excel Developer I think it's more true to say that the tax cuts were from the Congressional Republicans rather than the short fingered one.
DJ morning...anything in IWG please?
BE11:39am

.... anyway, any IPO that's open to retail investors for no reason other than brand kudos should probably carry a bit of a health warning automatically.

Tom Dalgleish Short fingers long pockets
11:39 am
undefined
DJ TomTom -25%...wasn't this a "bid target" not too long ago?
BE11:40am

IWG's a Credit Suisse downgrade.

IWG Plc (IWG:LSE): Last: 218.40, down 10.4 (-4.55%), High: 225.90, Low: 218.30, Volume: 2.60m
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Downgrade to Underperform: We see risks to near- and mid-term reported
numbers as growth accelerates, EPS vulnerability as and when the current
cycle comes to an end, tangible pressure on reported earnings numbers from the implementation of IFRS16, and the potential loss of operational
momentum following the departure of the CFO/COO. We downgrade to
Underperform (from Neutral) with a 200p (from 245p) price target. Our pre-IFRS16 2019-2020E EPS estimates fall by 8% and 7% respectively.

chopper bear itv getting burned again
BE11:41am

Numerous areas of risk: The implementation of IFRS16 will not change the
economics of the business but will lead, on our estimates, to an 18%
reduction in 2019E reported EPS due to the phasing of centre growth.
Accelerating network growth will, we think, also put pressure on earnings
and, while we see the strategic value of building the network in the longer
term in what remains a structurally growing market, this will compound
negative earnings momentum. In addition, the departure of the CFO/COO,
we think, puts the improved operational momentum in the US at risk. The
serviced office market is structurally growing but we think the rapid growth of both IWG and many of its peers leave it more vulnerable into any downturn. While this is not our core case in the coming years, we think it should be factored into valuation multiples. This series of risks means that we view the risk-reward balance as unattractive over the next 12 months.

undefined
11:43 am
BE11:43am

ITV's pre the capital markets day tomorrow, of course, around which there are numerous concerns.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 152.00, down 6 (-3.80%), High: 157.15, Low: 151.60, Volume: 6.32m
BE11:44am

Firstly on the Endemol Shine stuff mentioned yesterday, which suggested Carolyn McCall is at least willing to do a rights issue in pursuit of what we must these days call "content".

Flaneur Any analyst comment on Carneys -35% DPL gaffe?Surely hes killed the market in the short term at least?
11:44 am
BE11:45am

Secondly on the underlying reasons why she'd do that. As in, advertising's terrible.

Flaneur *should have said 'gaff gaffe'....
BE11:45am

And Berenberg's saying it's getting worse again.

BE11:45am

We are cutting our numbers to reflect lower revenue and more opex:
While our media buyer conversations suggest that the TV advertising
market is weakening, suggesting a worse run rate into 2019, the recently
announced strategic refresh by new CEO Carolyn McCall will result in
additional investment in the group in 2019. The combination of the two
will weigh on profits such that we cut EPS by 5% for 2019E and by 7% for
2020E. We think Bloomberg consensus EPS is as much as 15% too high for
2019E, while the company-compiled figure suggests a 10% gap versus our
figures. We reiterate our Hold rating and set a new price target of 155p.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Our latest conversations with media buyers suggest that client spend continues to drift in TV. While ITV is broadly holding its own in terms of commercial share, we now forecast ITV TV advertising revenue to fall by 1.5% this year, versus closer to 1% previously. Consensus assumes flat net advertising revenues (NAR). Yet September and October are both weakening, which does not bode well for November and December, although there is little visibility.

BE11:46am

While next year is still very much in
crystal ball territory, the nearly 4% decline that we forecast for Q4 2018
does not bode well for next year. 2018 benefited from the FIFA World Cup,
while 2019 will have a lesser event – the Rugby World Cup, which is being
held in Japan and thus in a difficult time zone for viewing and
commercialisation. In the meantime, we believe that Brexit-related
uncertainty will weigh on commercial activity. We thus reduce our forecast
for ITV NAR to -3.8% for 2019. Consensus is broadly flat.

FATDAZ @flaneur re the Carney comment as I understand that was one possible outcome from a series of stress tests not a definitive prediction
Tom Dalgleish I have never liked companies buying their suppliers
BE11:47am

As we've said previously, "conversations with media buyers" always seem to be "everything's much more brilliant than we thought last month" or "everything's much much worse than we thought last month" .....

Flaneur @fatdaz - but it was the one that got headlines on the BBC until they realised half of social media thought it was a good idea and had to pull it. Telegraph had a great cartoon about it...
alewis2005 @Flaneur please say it is so - could do with an affordable flat somewhere in london
FATDAZ what about this talk of a UK version of netflix to be kicked by a buyout of UKTV by the BBC ?
Pharma @FATDAZ, but he made no attempt to clarify the point after all the headlines screamed "Carney says houses to crash 35%".
GBKrona @Flaneur - the -35% was just a modelling scenario, I thought. Was clarified widely after initial misreporting...
11:48 am
BE11:48am

A person could speculate whether the opinion might be influenced by whether it was expressed before or after they went to the toilets in Soho House.

BE11:48am

Anyway, here's Berenberg on the strategy day.

BE11:48am

For those who feared a kitchen-sinking of numbers by incoming CEO Carolyn McCall, the key messages, to be expanded upon at this week’s capital markets day (CMD), should have provided comfort. ITV will invest a net £25m in 2019, with savings offsetting investment from 2020. Based on this investment, ITV aims to grow online and direct-to-consumer (DTC)
revenues, and to deliver a 5% CAGR in terms of content production. All this is sensible, but not aggressive enough to fully offset weaker NAR.
Management’s quandary is that a more aggressive strategy would entail
higher investment, and greater risk, neither of which we think would be
welcomed by investors given where ITV sits strategically and cyclically.

GBKrona @Flaneur - Carney clarified this, e.g. in Dublin the day after, but media did not report
FATDAZ @Pharma fair point though he did eventually release a statement I believe
alewis2005 @GBKrona that's because 'actually house priced might not be as bad as announced' isn't a sexy headline statement
11:50 am
BE11:50am

(@Flaneur: I direct you to the answer we gave at the time -- https://ftalphavil...tslive/2018-09-14/ .)

undefined
TheManwithaLongChin Surely it would be less work for analysts to comment on the headlines which aren't misrepresentations.
Pharma @FATDAZ the problem is lots of people will believe it was intentional (including me). The initial story on p1 will always make more of an impression than the p12 technical clarification.
FATDAZ @Pharma of course
Widnes wonders do we have pay 35% less for the housing allowance?
BE11:53am

Okay .......... so ignoring the ROTR's retreat into the most boring cul-de-sac of DPL ..... what else we got?

GBKrona @BE - Trump / China - any comments? (Jamie's piece on AV is very good)
11:54 am
BE11:54am

There's the Zalando warning.

FATDAZ Is it too late for ITV to move to some kind of subscription model ?
Upaswellasdown late morning all. Any comments on listed brokers following news of Santander's interest in Peel Hunt?
BE11:54am

Revenues now low end of 20-25% guidance, adjusted EBIT now E150-190m vs. E220-270m previously

Pharma Would be interesting to run an analysis of the correlation between the two sides of ML.Today would probably run R^2 = 0.2 (higher before Flaneur set us off).
BE11:55am

Weather gets the blame. Too hot, too cold. You know the routine. We've seen it enough from the nonline retailers.

Flaneur @GBKrona - The problem Carney has is that he is hoist on his own petard; everything he announces is just a modelling scenario, so all of it can be ignored/dismissed from now on.@BE - its not boring - Carney tried to scaremonger (again) and ended making a fool of himself. This is the govenor of the BoE in an interview with the BBC economics editor - its not some kid who photocopied the wrong press release.
11:56 am
BE11:56am

Kepler to summarise.

wayneJ And now, for regular viewers, we go to our 'Frock Retail' segment....with our reporter on the ground.......
BE11:56am

Zalando mentioned as reasons for the profit warning an unusually long
period of warm weather which caused a traffic decline and delayed the
collection switch to the autumn collection, leading to higher discounts of
the current collection. Usually, September and October are two marginheavy
months as the new merchandise arrives and is usually sold at original
prices. As a consequence, it cut its sales growth range from the lower half
of the 20-25% range to around the low end of the range. The adj. EBIT line
has been reduced to a wide range of EUR150-190m (from the low end of
the EUR220-270m range) indicating that it is still early in the quarter.

Lemmy Upaswellasdown: there's a piece on ft.com about Cenkos results if you want
BE11:57am

Lower sales growth immediately hit Zalando’s business model as its
fulfilment costs cannot be leveraged sufficiently because its infrastructure
projects with new warehouses and customer proposition are ongoing and
the company will probably not and is not willing to adjust costs to protect
its margin. The impact will be seen at an EBIT margin at below 3%.

FATDAZ re Zalando never looked at the site before but just found this a knitted hoodie for £309.00 https://www.zalando.co.uk/emporio-armani-jumper-nero-ea822q00i-q11.html
A. M. (@Pharma: R2=0.2 doesn't sound like much..)
11:57 am
BE11:58am

(@Flaneur: isn't £ at its highest since July?)

Waterloo No China talks currently according to Wilber Ross. Hopes the tariffs will 'modify' Chinese behaviour. Can see that going down well in Bejing
FATDAZ re Zalando not surprised they are warning if thats typical of their product range
wayneJ @FATDAZ - may I remind you of the oath for the ROTR - thou shalt only buy hoodies from SuperDry; and only SuperDry shall be the provider of the hoodies you shall own
Pharma @A.M. exactly. Not sure it would be possible to back-construct most ML sessions if all you had were separate files of the left and right portions.Note: Not complaining - it's perfect just as it is.
BE11:58am

They say medium term outlook unchanged, and it's a market problem not a Zalando problem.

wayneJ What is the read across to Asos / Boo etc -
A. M. @Pharma: hmm. you can find markers, I suppose. Sync by ticker symbols and some delay, then?
BE11:59am

We cut our EBIT estimates on average by 19% for the years 2018/19/20 and sales by 1%. With the lower estimates and an adjusted EV/sales forecast from 1.8x to 1.5x we reduce our TP from EUR46 to EUR40. Zalando had its rough EV/sales multiple at 1.2x during the summer period 2016 but its long term average is at 1.8x. We keep our hold rating as we would attribute the profit warning to an external effect which should lead to a margin rebound in 2019.

Upaswellasdown thanks Lemmy. Was also interested in Numis - seems to be outperforming
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

Similar from Barclays.

BE12:00pm

We expect the stock to be under pressure this morning but aren’t sure there is anything thesis altering here (although we need more detail on the 6 Nov at the full Q3 report). They explicitly point to continued good KPIs on active customers, order frequency and Partner Program - the issue is with basket size, which can be impacted by weather. We are Overweight.

FATDAZ @wayneJ Lol I actually don't own anything by super dry as too old lol but the days of paying £300 for a jumper are long gone for most i would have thought
wayneJ (Hint 'ebay: SuperDry Hoodie' - considerably cheaper than the ones you pointed to)
BE12:00pm

The argument here is that you don't pay 64x times earnings based on one quarter.

wayneJ Does a Ferrari warning impact the spin out of various sporting / lux brands within VW? Indeed is VW going to do a Ford and sell its premium brands at distressed prices at the bottom of the cycle?
12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

So if you believe the weather excuse, fine, nothing changes.

FATDAZ @waynej good point , and the more I look at zalando the more it looks like an online urban outfitters
Pharma @FATDAZ, but that one has something on the front vaguely reminiscent of National Socialism. What's not to like?
BE12:02pm

You're going to be less comfortable if, however, you believe that there might be something structurally wrong with a company warning twice in six weeks with midpoint earnings down 30pc over the period.

wayneJ There is an interesting MS chart circulating showing prices of online and physical frock retailers. Clue - online is not always cheaper
FATDAZ @wayneJ will look out for that
BE12:04pm

And if the structural thing is increasing delivery expectations, constantly rising IT costs, a more aggressive high street either throwing money at fast fashion logistics and/or literally fighting for survival ......

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

................. then you're looking at similar things across the sector.

wayneJ @Fatdaz - 10th Sep MS European Internet note
BE12:05pm

Including at Boohoo, which to remind is giving an increasing share of earnings to marketplaces it doesn't own 100%.

Boohoo Group PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 180.95, up 3.6 (+2.03%), High: 182.20, Low: 170.50, Volume: 10.55m
12:05 pm
ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 5,702, down 344 (-5.69%), High: 5,798, Low: 5,642, Volume: 445.72k
Blank canvas thanks for everything today. Entertaining and informative as usual
undefined
Soundbuy Aye, cheers............
FATDAZ RE modern clothing retailers I was and still am horrified by the scale of unsold stock at likes of H&M revealed earlier in the year ( billions $) against that background I would question the economics of the whole sector
FATDAZ @wayne j thanks

No time to mention Sinclair Pharma's 32 offer from something called Huadong Medicine.

wayneJ I am confused - if the pricing is higher and the fulfilment poorer; and the customers are being stuffed full of credit - what is there to like with online retail

https://www.reuter...utch-idUSKCN1LX1NG

Personally, I'm still a wee bit lost on why it matters.

12:10 pm

Is there really such a thing as a "UK investor" any more? How many active managers are constricted by a UK FTSE listing?

wayneJ @Fadaz I think it is called #Trending63 - you will find Exhibit 1 interesting

BE12:11pm

The Unilever price suggests the argument's somewhere between negligible and nonexistent to current value.

wayneJ European Internet #trending63: Yandex, Delivery Hero, Ocado, Boohoo, ASOS, Scout24 ----- yep the editorial boys had a fun time with that title.
12:11 pm
Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 4,250, down 3.5 (-0.08%), High: 4,267, Low: 4,244, Volume: 725.75k
BE12:11pm

Anyway.

Pharma @BE perhaps matters more for the long-term value of ULVR, if the NL move leads to less pressure on management (you can reasonably argue both ways on this, depending on your view of the delights of quarterly reporting).
wayneJ If Primark is priced at 100 - they show Boo at 156, and Asos at 224 vs Zara at 271 !

That'll do. Go read Jamie in tariffs if you like: https://ftalphavil...-tariffs-on-China/

wayneJ (H&M at 174, M&S 227, Next 208)

12:13 pm
BE12:13pm

And then go read me, over here, on airlines and stuff like that: https://www.ft.com...-94b2-17176fbf93f5

wayneJ Does Donnie's list lead to an inflationary shock to the US?

Ta for all the comments apart from the house price ones. Back tomorrow. Afternoon all.
